description:
The best thing about this place is the fried chicken. Food is waaaaaay over priced for what it is. Clearly they are just taking advantage of the lack of Korean food in the area. They charge $8 for banchans which are always free at Korean restaurants and the bulgogi was too soggy and saucy (the meat was too thin). You can hardly taste the meat it feels more like you are eating sauce/paste. 

Service is definitely great and staff was really friendly. Might come back again but if we do will just get more fried chicken. Was really hoping the food would be awesome because this place is so close!
author: Julia M.

description: Like most in San Francisco, I'm a total sucker for trendy takes on Asian cuisine (Burma Love, Hawker Fare, Dancing Yak), and Foxsister did not disappoint! Brought a crew here for my birthday dinner after having a wonderful experience the first time around. The kimchi nacho cheese dip was beyond my wildest appetizer dreams, and the soju slushies were a fantastic vehicle for what is usually not my favorite form of booze. If you're looking for totally authentic Korean food this probably is not your place, but if you are interested in fusion interpretations in a fun atmosphere I would definitely recommend!
author: Sarah S.

description:
quick tips:
- the frozé (rosé slushie with soju) is just perfect
- quick, friendly service
- it's pretty loud and dark

- HIGH LIGHTS -
The frozé was actually incredible. It was the perfect consistency: thick, but easy to drink. The rosé flavor was not too strong, and the drink as a whole was light and refreshing.

The sweet and spicy wings were very flavorful and the skin was thin and lightly crispy. A basket came with 6 full wings (drumette, wingette, tip).

The beef galbi was juicy and boneless, and came on a sizzling plate.

- low LIGHTS -
The kimchi stew tasted flat, like a generic tomato soup. I wish I had nicer things to say, but it was too watery and we couldn't find the pork belly it was supposed to come with. Also, I'm not sure where the tomato flavor came from. Unfortunately, by the time it reached our table, it was not bubbling/sizzling.

Banchan costs $8. Yes, this is San Francisco, but I'd love to see the tradition of complimentary banchan upheld. Head's up, it includes 4 dishes: kimchi, bean sprouts, dried anchovies, and mushrooms. I wish the menu listed these.

The watermelon slushie was just ok for me. It tasted like watermelon that was too ripe (lol, I'm a princess, I know). But it's hard to compare another drink to the perfect frozé.

- re: HIGH LIGHTS -
The service was great, especially for their 2nd day. Our waiter was attentive and fun to talk to.

The space had a fun party vibe. There were strings of little lights and fun artwork on the walls. The music is pretty loud, making this a great location for a group dinner. Probably not the best place for a serious date.

- OVERALL -
I can't get over how awesome the frozé was. Can you tell? I've only mentioned it 3 times. While this restaurant seems great for groups, I can't wait to return to Foxsister and get a frozé and basket of wings for myself.
author: Jiann M.

description: Overpriced and their "fusion" Korean is a nicer way to describe underwhelming not-even-close-to-authentic. Went with 3 friends for dinner and the live DJ's music was so loud, we couldn't even hear each other at the table even though we were screaming at top of our lungs to talk. Definitely not coming back here.
author: Lara H.

description: Everything from the food to the decor is fun and unpretentious. The chef-owner Brandon is a badass with an amazing vision to bring approachable Korean street food to 24th Street. Get the dumplings, the fresh crab noodles, and the wings. The BBQ shortribs are to die for, and don't you dare skip the boozy slushies !
author: Nicole S.

description: Great Korean Food in the Mission District, service was outstanding too. Really enjoyed the Fried Oysters and the Mushroom Rice Cakes. They actually mix really well together.  I would totally go back as this was a great atmosphere and value.
author: Carrie H.

description:
i had a nice time at foxsister, but definitely wont be suggesting this spot for serious eats. it's a nice place for friends to gather and drink soju/beers and have a few snacks, but that's about it. wait for 2 people for bar seating even was 30 minutes last saturday.  the place was popping. we got a bottle of the peach soju (DELICIOUS) for $15 and shared it standing at the ledge they had at the back. when the bar finally cleared, we sat down and ordered the medium sized wings (half n half is offered, which i appreciate, because i can never decide on a single flavor), the oxtail soup with rice, the banchan ($8!!) and the pancake, which came last and it was burnt on the bottom.  the wings were pretty good, but a slightly on the salty side. i also dont particularly enjoy the shape of the wings, makes it super hard to eat. the oxtail soup came out next, and it was pretty good - especially on a chilly evening. the rice cakes are nice n soft, but the soup base itself was a little bland, and the veggies in the dish werent integrated with the soup at all. banchan was good - but shouldnt this be free, or at least cheaper the $8? dinner for two was a little over $100 for mediocre korean food in the mission in a loud space. i think things are generally going in the right direction, but have room for improvement for sure.

the decor of the restaurant is very cute though, and makes me think that i need lanterns and string lights in my apartment as well!
author: Christina L.

description:
as a korean-american who grew up eating korean food errday, i don't get the hype. i wanted to love it, i really did, but this place left me sad and still on the search for a korean spot to call home. 

the kimchi stew tasted flat and lacked depth in flavor. the shrimp and chive dumplings were just ok...the mungbean pancake was aight. the best thing was probably the kimchi fried rice, bc pork belly makes the world go 'round. overall everything was mediocre and waaaaaaaaaaaaayyyyyyyy-y-yyyy overpriced. i was legit sad when the bill came. 

the only thing i really enjoyed was the ambiance and the bazaar fantasy movies played at the bar. i really wanted to like you foxsister, but it seems you will be joining my growing list of b-team korean restaurants in the bay.
author: Christa C.

description: I was totally blown away by this place. Didn't know much about it and hadn't read about it before, and I was so pleasantly surprised by it all. The ambiance was super cool and fun and whimsical - kind of a nice escape from the craziness of life and city. And the food was excellent. Each dish was full of flavor and delight. I will go back again and again!
author: Beth G.

description:
what a super fun dinner- I went back twice in 1 week. I really love casual, tasty restaurants with friends where I can be loud, listen to my good music and chill. Foxsister does not disappoint. 
loving the soju slushies- watermelon is my favorite, beware they sneak up on you. 
plus they serve hitachino- a Japanese white ale that's hard to find. 
1st time we ate the nacho cheese , dumplings (really liked the shape/texture), fried chicken wings (the sticky sweet sauce, not the OG recipe) and short ribs (sooooooo delish). 
tonight we ate the nacho cheese again, dumplings again, the stew and oxtail marrow soup plus the tofu bulgogi that are my new favorite. 
the broth is so favorable and rich- I could just drink it ! 

The ambiance of the restaurant is also worth noting as being inviting and perfect for a group. I'll definitely be back!
author: Marissa B.

description: Random dinner on a random night lead me here.  Korean fried chicken, pickles, crab noodles...ya you name it. Not totally fair to compare it to a standard Korean place because it's got a twist or two.  But oh man, that fried chicken was pretty legit. It's kinda dark and the menu I got was black text on red paper...so be ready to be that jerk with the iPhone torch reading the menu.
author: David S.

description: I love this place! I had my birthday dinner here and they were so accommodating through the whole process! Kristina was very professional and responded to my emails very quickly during the planning process and she worked with me on the menu to accommodate for vegetarians. This is the place you take people from out of town that want the local SF experience aside from the touristy shit. Atmosphere is on point. Not only is the staff friendly, the food is Amazing! Get the mushroom rice cakes. Sorry for throwing my doughnut holes, I was a bit tipsy by dessert.
author: Melody A.

description:
This place was fantastic!!  Right from the get go, I really enjoyed the experience.  The booth seats along the side and front gave the place a great look.

The wait staff was super friendly and helpful in recommending quality dishes.  They could not have been more friendly and attentive; truly enhancing the experience.  

All the food we got was delicious!  An amazing combination of authentic Korean and modern takes on dishes.  All the dumplings and the pork bulgogi were fantastic, but the fried chicken was the best.  Both styles are amazing!

I cannot recommend this highly enough!
author: Jason F.

description: I'm a huge fan of Korean food, and perhaps I'm spoiled by NYC and NJ pricing, but I think the food here is very overpriced. It's a nice cozy spot to come and get drinks and snacks, but I wouldn't say that a full course dinner here is worth the $$.
author: Justina E.

description:
The food was great but the service was eh. 

We ordered the crispy mung bean pancake and an order of "Some Chicken". Both were really delicious and I'd come back for the food. 

It was the service that left a bad taste in our mouth. We received the chicken pretty quickly which I was delighted as I was pretty hungry. After 25 minutes, our pancakes had not been delivered. I finally flagged someone down which they said it was on the way. 

After 10 minutes, the waitress apologized and said she didn't hear our order and it would be coming shortly. 

My question is, if she didn't hear the rest of our order, why were we sitting around for 25 minutes? It wasn't very busy during this time at all. 

The pancakes finally arrived and it was a crispy slice of heaven! 

When we got our bill, there was a beer we didn't order on there. So not only were we ignored for 25 minutes, the rest of our food arrived 45 minutes after we ordered, they had made another mistake. 

Come for the food, but try to ignore the bad service like how you'll be ignored.
author: Enoch L.

description: Great meal, many items had a gluten free option and all very tasty. Everything prepared with great care and served timely with a smile and friendly attitude!  The frozen beverages were fantastic! Atmosphere was friendly, inviting and fun!
author: Wendy H.

description: Holy shit y'all the chicken. So next level. It says I have to keep writing but really that's it. Try all the sauces.
author: Kaia R.

description: Great service and staff. (Ashley was sooo nice!) Yummy food. Order the mushroom rice cake and garlic soy fried chicken.
author: Lesley M.

description:
I had my eye on this restaurant ever since it was announced. Maybe I hyped it up too much, but I left feeling that everything was ok or good, but nothing was great for the price point (except maybe the frozen drinks). 

We ordered the banchan, oxtail and bone marrow stew, fried chicken wings (both the spicy and sweet and the garlic soy), the mung bean pancake, crab noodles and pork bulgolgi. So we definitely tried a lot on the menu. Probably my favorite thing was the garlic soy wings. 

We also had kind of a weird service issue - may just be because it just opened. We didn't receive a glass of wine that we ordered and we requested it removed from the bill. The server's initial response was "I could have sworn I brought it out." So, that was more of a battle than expected. 

We will probably try this place again since it's so close by. I will revert back once we do.
author: Brigitte J.

description:
TL;DR food was decent but expensive. Wings are good, but slightly on the salty side.

Soju was $15. I can't get over the fact that a bottle of soju was $15. At a Korean market you'll find soju at roughly $2 just for reference. At most Korean bars the price ranges from $3-8. 

They also charge for banchan which in my book is a huge no-no for Korean restaurants. The only thing keeping this from being a 2-star rating is my compassion for restaurant owners who have to pay high overheads due to soaring rent and cost of living.

Pitchers are served here and are actually much more affordable to than the soju, so if you want to drink some beers and enjoy wings with friends this could be the place for you. The wife and I ordered the Garlic soy wings, sweet & spicy wings, pork kimchee fried rice, fried oysters, and a bottle of $15 soju. 

The wings are good. 5 actual wings (or 10 if you go to an American wing place) are served with each order. Sweet and spicy was our favorite. Fried oysters were delicious, crunchy yet juicy on the inside. The fried rice was meh. 

If I were to go back, it would only be for the wings and pitchers, and the fact that it's walking distance from where I live. 

The restaurant is also located very close to the 24th/mission Bart station. Parking sucks in that area so try to take public transportation or Lyft.

Lastly there is a bar and TV if you want to come watch a game, but fyi half the restaurant is out of view from the TV.
author: Andrew E.

description: This place is a literal gem in the mission because it's hard to find Korean here, especially got Korean. Kimchi nacho cheese with pork rinds. That's what sold me. You get a huge portion so share with a friend. The wings are awesome too, Ask for "around the world" style if you want to try all the flavors. Batter is light and crispy. I am also a huge fan of the spicy pork. It comes with lettuce, thinly sliced daikon, fermented bean paste, garlic and jalapeño to make a little taco. You gotta try this place!
author: Jeff K.

description: Very good good all around. The potstickers were exceptionally delicious. A little expensive but probably worth it overall. I plan on going back.
author: Joseph B.

description:
Delicious half-order ("stack") of ribs, enough to satiate a late-night craving, though a bit pricey at $16.

Pleasant bar service.
author: Inigo M.

description: The place looks like it would be a lowkey cheap bites place, but is actually really pricey for the amount of food that you get. I shared the Dungeness crab noodle and mung bean pancake with a friend, paid about $21 and was still hungry afterwards. Regardless it is a pretty cool atmosphere inside. Fried chicken might be more worth it here
author: Claire L.

description: Nice place to try out. The food was pretty average here. Wasn't a big fan of the stew-soup. The black bean garlic noodles were good.
author: S K.

description: First time trying this place, upon recommendation by my friend. Hands down, one of the best dining experiences I've had in a while. The space itself is lit with colorful string lights and lanterns, all reflected by the black tiles and tables, creating a vibrant wonderland. We ordered the Fox Food salad, spicy tofu buns, a basket of fried chicken, and the octopus rice cakes. AMAZING. The tofu was excellent, perfectly seasoned and soft. They also offer three different types of fried chicken, but you can get multiple kinds within one order. Our favorite was the garlic soy, with sweet and spicy a close second. The dessert menu was enticing, but we were too stuffed full of great eats to try any. Next time!
author: Odette N.

description: $8 for banchan (kim chee, pickles and snacks oh my!).  Any korean restaurant that charges for kim chee should be shut down.  Enough said.
author: Eddy H.

description:
Delicious food but expensive for what it was and the neighborhood. I ordered a glass of sparkling wine and my husband a mug of Tecate. We split the dumplings which were delicious! He had half a rack of ribs with a side of rice... and it couldn't have been more than 1/3 cup of rice... I ordered the crab noodles which were also tasty but lacking in the crab area. 

All of that was $84.... which didn't feel appropriate. 

Service was great, food delicious but not worth the price.
author: Kyra W.

description:
Had a work event here for 50 people and everything was great! The food was tasty, there was a lot of variety, and the flavors were really good - Korean influenced but not just a regular run of the mill offer. We had:

-Banchan (5 different options, all tasty- those marinated mushrooms !)
-veggie dumplings
-pork and beef dumplings (so good)
- Dungeness Crab noodle (jap chae noodle- could have used more crab but I would always say that about dishes with crab)
-Mushroom Rice Cakes (a tteok dish)
- Pork Fried Rice (noms)
- Grilled Kalbi (flavorful and not overly fatty)
-Yuba Bulgogi 
-Grilled Pork Bulgogi
-Rice
-Garlic Soy Fried Chicken - really nice
-Sweet and Spicy Fried Chicken - love the flavor!
-Rack of Ribs
-Bok Choy

What's amazing was the level of service here. The dishes were timed well with banchans being out when we arrived and everything coming out at a nice cadence where we didn't have too much food sitting out, but were never waiting on anything either. It's a great skill to serve 50 people in a reception style and have things go well so if you're thinking about an event here- do it!

My favorite was the soju slushies. We had a lot of people that were fans of the Watermelon Ginger Lime but the clear, clear winner was the Froze. I don't know why it's called a froze, it's not really rose flavored like all the other frozes I have had (mostly at pool parties/ cabana service in Vegas) but was a thicker, raspberry flavor and amazing. I don't think it should be called a rose but it should be ordered as it's very, very good.
author: Kajal G.

description: should've made a reservation, waited for an hour, its alright were just chilling, the place is looking cool with all the lanterns, painting and lights i was pretty entertained. Parking is not easy, as it was the day of the dead event/parade. Didn't get to take pictures of food we just dug in, pretty good amount to share for two people, we got the kalbi beef ribs. Yum! soju slushies were great too! Great service as well. Cost will have to pay more than $100 just for two people. Would come back (and will make a reservation) next time lol
author: Chey I.

description: A great time and a fun atmosphere.  Tasty food that scratches the itch for tasty wings, bar food, etc. I'm not sure I would order pickup from the restaurant as a large part of my enjoyment is the atmosphere and experience.
author: Bret H.

description: Arrived at 7:40, reservation at 8. Didn't get seated until 8:20, didn't get to order cause I don't know what the waiter kept doing in the back, until 8:40. Waiter came by and looked at us and still didn't get it, i had to ask if we could order. The food was ok, I'd give it a 4/5. Not going back.
author: Chris H.

description: I've been coming here quite a bit lately and I've always had a great time. Love the Korean bar bites. Some highlights are the pork cracklings with cheese dip, all the dumplings are great, crab noodle is delicious, and the garlic and soy fried chicken is amazing. This is a great place to go in lieu of a formal dinner. You get great food paired with beer and soju in with a lively atmosphere.
author: Phil C.

description:
Let me start this off by saying I was previously very intimidated by Korean food, the whole fermented thing freaks me out. The Foxsister team talked me through the menu and found the perfect meal for me and got me to try new things--which I ended up loving! yay for expanding palettes! 
I loved the Soju Slushies (so much that I tried all of them). Super innovative and delicious. My favorite was the peach while my dining partner loved the watermelon. 
I have to say that my favorite part was the vibe of the whole place. The chef, Brandon Kirksey, was in and out of the kitchen throughout the night. Super sweet and TALL dude. I loved the energetic punk playlist and bold decor. So many places in the city go for the minimalist thing it was a great change of pace. The team was great and down to earth. 
I could go on! Check it out yourself!
author: Molly S.

description: Overrated & over priced. YES for Slow cooker ribs, but NO for fried chicken, rice cakes, or cast iron dishes. You are definitely not getting what you paid for, all spicy flavors for different dishes were the same, nothing interesting.
author: Ellen h.

description: Roommates took me here for my bday in April. Super cool vibe! We had the kimchi nacho cheese dip = amazing love the pork rinds! We also had the tacos which were a little too fatty for me. Roommate liked them. The shorts ribs were probably my favorite and my roommate ate all the dumplings. Lately we had "some chicken" that was a mix of garlic and the sweet and spicy. Good stuff! Definitely trying to get back here ASAP!
author: Kimberly J.

description: The service and atmosphere were excellent. The food on and off menu was pretty unique in my dining experience. I was really impressed with the calamari jerky, I am looking forward to getting back here again.
author: Ken L.

description:
In a sea of sameness, Foxsister sticks out. 
 The food is killer, the atmosphere is fun and they have booze slurpees!! 
 The kind of place you can drop in for a bite and a beer or celebrate a birthday with friends.  Don't miss the octopus rice cakes, bulgogi and dank fried chicken. 
I can't wait to go back and I just left.
author: Emily C.

description: We had fried chicken, octopus rice cakes and kimchee nachos.  We were disappointed at food.  They were not tasty and not authentic korean food.  Food came out super slow and overpriced. Soju Slushies were good.
author: EunJoo C.

description: Tasty food and pretty fun ambiance but small portions for the price. If they just gave you more food it would be perfect. Probably will return.
author: Carolyn N.

description: I love fried chicken, unfortunately, just not here. Underwhelming take on korean bar food. Flavor was lacking across the board - calamari, rice cake...  Excessively overpriced for what it is.  Service was excellent so thanks for that.
author: E L.

description: Love this place. Can't get enough of their soju/hite boilermakers. Go for the fried chicken, stay for the kimchi & ribs! Nom
author: S S.

description: So yummy. The pork buns were amazing as were the short ribs. In fact - everything was so good. Also the pina colada slushie? YUM! Such a fun girls night location.
author: Tali F.

description: Up beat R&B Music on point along with some tasty amazing food!  Soooo good! Love the fact the menu changes up every few weeks too...to try new things!
author: Robert G.

description: This restaurant has become one of my favorites in San Francisco.. The service is superb, the food exquisite. My dish I will be sure to order again is the pork dumplings and kimchi cucumbers!!! Let's not get me on the Sojus.. Those are Devine!!! I would recommend this restaurant for anyone who would like great service and excellent food and atmosphere.. The Chef and his staff are friendly and approachable.... Can't wait till I visit again!!
author: Sheryl K.

description: Good expensive korean food for non Koreans.  Great idea for having a hipster korean restaurant. Makes it sound expensive.
author: Fatty A.

description: The korean chicken wings are amazing! Also loved the ribs! This is a very lively place in the evening and they have great and unique drinks as well: alcohol containing slushies, whiskey barrel aged soju, sparkling apple/grape wine, and of course Hite beer. Our waitress Ashley was great, I kept accidentally dropping a chopstick and I think she would hear it and come running back with another chop stick for me. Also she had soju shots with the table! Great vibe in there and I will be back again soon!
author: Mike O.

description:
Honestly the worst Korean spot I have ever ate at.  Don't waste your money on this place, a ton of better spots and cheaper places also.  Coco bang, toyosey, manna, etc.  Come here for Korean and you will waste your money on unauthentic Korean food.  

Worst in the city....
author: Kevin W.

description: The ambiance was really fun but the food was very disappointing.  The pancake was soggy.  The hellfire soup was very bland. The fried rice was pretty tasty. But overall the meal was disappointing especially for the price.
author: Christina C.

description:
Dive hipster Korean fusion.

Good drinks.  Food so-so, trying too hard to be innovative.  Service was nice and they came around within delicious slushy shots, but forgot the rice I ordered.  Pricey compared with traditional Korean food.

Banchan meh
Fried chicken meh
Egg custard pretty good

3 stars, where most of the good Korean in SF gets 4 and I'd give five to the best in LA, Tokyo and Seoul.
author: adam s.

description: I want to like this place because it's close by and I like the food but the 4 of us got food poisoning :(
author: That G.

description:
The soba salad I ordered was tasty.

BUT

The restaurant was WAY too loud. 
The food is a bit over priced.
Decor is distracting and overwhelming.
The ambiance will deter me from coming back.
author: Lily A.

description:
Ok... I'm giving Foxsister a 5/5 but not necessarily for the food but the environment, decor, and staff. Foxsister is a super fun spot to go with a few friends, kick back a few beers, and enjoy some fried chicken. I wasn't over the moon for everything I've ordered here, but a) there is very little (see: basically none) good Korean food in the Mission, so as a local I'll take what I can get, and b) the entire experience was just so enjoyable that I can give a pass on not totally amazing Korean food.

I'm not a big fan of flavored Soju... but their slushies are delicious. Just ask for a sample if you don't want to take the plunge.
author: Ben G.

description: Wowza! This place is frikin rad. Korean inspired deliciousness that surprises you with every bite. Awesome service, fun atmosphere, and the slushies... #Frozeallday. My favorite fare so far...Short ribs be hella tender.  Melt in your mouth. The homemade crisps n cheese dip is ridiculous. Best I've had in years. Oxtail soup...so rich. I hear the chef preps it over 3 days! Wings...sweet n spicy for sure. Dessert:the rice pudding was great if you're not looking for too sweet. But that tea custard topped with toasted pine nuts and boba ballz...Dayum! Welcome to the neighborhood Foxsister. You are damn fine.
author: Alex S.

description:
So happy to have a great Korean place in the Mission!

I went here with a friend and was really impressed. The atmosphere is lively and fun. Our server couldn't have been nicer or more accommodating. 

We ordered a few things and shared everything:

- Kimchi Nacho Cheese Dip: unexpectedly delicious! Pork cracklins + hot cheese dip. Can't go wrong with that.

- Pork Fried Rice: simple but great - the pork was nice and crispy

- Grilled Kalbi Shortrib: excellent flavor; this is meant to be put in lettuce wraps with soybean paste

- Some Chicken: half a chicken - delightfully spicy, and I liked the fact that they provided some boneless chicken pieces as well

We had the Soju Froze slushies which were good :) We also had the Hite beer - came out super cold which is awesome.

Service was a bit on the slow side but given that they just opened, I'm sure that won't be an issue after a week or two.

Will definitely be returning!
author: Matt S.

description: Really yum, quality food. Went for a pre xmas family gathering, they took reservations and sat us in a comfortable booth. Very fun interior and concept-- ordered a ton of stuff but highlights were the bulgogi, anything with rice cakes, and those mushrooms in the box choy. Chef came out and picked up dishes just to check out the floor, seemed like a great environment to work.
author: Nina S.

description: This place is Awesome! It provides a fantastic flavor explosion with strong Korean influences while offering something for everyone. Probably the best ribs I've ever had, fantastic fried chicken, amazing oysters and Wow, the frozen drinks were incredible. Very excited I can now enjoy all of these things in the same place; Ill be back for sure; ENJOY!!!
author: David G.

description: We loved this place! Great atmosphere, friendly service. The red booths, the purple glitter bar and slushy machines are a nice pop of color. As for the food: The Kimchi Nacho Cheese Dip with Pork Cracklings was a great way to start. The Dumplings and Dungeness Crab Noodles were delicious. The Sweet and Spicy Chicken was fantastic. The Slow Cooked Ribs were my favorite. Fall off the bone, melt in your mouth tender. I should have ordered a rack instead of a stack because they were so good I ordered another helping. I might have ordered a 3rd but the Pork Fried Rice sent me over the top. Filled with big chunks of pork and lots of flavor. My daughter loved the chocolate cupcake with the sparkler. We can't wait to go back and try some more of the menu. Foxsister is a hit! Try it for yourself you'll be glad you did.
author: Gene L.

description: I'm so happy to support great food and a good atmosphere in my neighborhood. Foxsister serves up comfort food realness! The food and service are worth the wait! Basically, order everything and try it for yourself! No leaks!!
author: Ali E.

description: I love, love, love this place.  The food and drinks are fantastic.  The venue is energizing.  It has quite an eclectic vibe to it. I can't wait to go back!
author: Alyssa L.

description: By far one of the best restaurants I have ever dined at! The ambiance was amazing with its dark unground look and bright neon signs. The food was spectacular, especially their delicious sauces. I could get enough until I saw the bathroom... IT WAS THE BEST BATHROOM IVE EVER BEEN IN! But I'll let you see it for yourself. Definitely will be visiting fo sister again and bringing more friends!!
author: Sophie O.

description: I've been here a couple of times since they opened - once sat at the bar and ordered food, second with a larger group for food & drinks. Both times I had very positive experiences. The atmosphere is fun and lively. The food is delicious (a few of my favorites are the pork bulgogi, garlic soy chicken wings, and pork & beef dumplings). To top it off, staff is super friendly and attentive. I'll definitely be back in the future!
author: Laura W.

description: This place is amazing, the food is totally different and it's amazingly well crafted. You may think it's another Korean place but you'd be mistaken if you think that. For example, take the wings, they're not just any wings but coated with sweet n spicy gochujang sauce was out of this world. Writing about it makes me crave it even more. Then the Dungess crab noodles, now these came with potato starch vermicelli that were actually clear. I'd rate these 4.5 stars but the five star dish and the winner of the day was spicy octopus rice cakes. If there's only one dish you're gonna order here, this is gonna be it. I wish I'd taken pics, but man the food is worth coming back again and again. Also, I've been told that the executive chef is from The Slanted Door so I guess the finesse in the food is understandable.
author: N N.

description: Decently tasty Korean food with an element of fusion. But dessert were lacking and pretty loud. Would go back! A good option for Asian food in the Mission.
author: Eve H.

description: Best food in town!!  great neighborhood spot. Love love love it. Soju slushies!!! Soju slushies! Soju slushies!
author: Brianne H.

description: This place rips! I had chicken wings, 4 soju drinks and a rad kimchi thing that I can't recall the name of. Nice to have a Korean chicken spot in the Mission, and it's nice that another DIY Mom-and-pop spot is open in the neighborhood.
author: George R.

description: Lots of fun, played movie classics like Big Lebowski and fear and loathing while serving fun food. Dumplings were on point, got the rib (lettuce wrap version) and very tasty but would have preferred duck and pancakes from yank sing. Soju and rice wine were shared at the table. The rice wine was unfiltered sake meets squirt so we didn't run it back but the soju kept pouring. They did this funny thing where they scooped the top of the lemon, which makes sense but think I will remain a wedge man. Let's see, also had crab noodles and fried chicken. Noodles were tasty but since this is the flour and water crew I expected avant-garde. Dried fried chicken, which I guess was the classic, was lovely while the wet was overwhelming with flavor.
author: Brendan M.

description: This fills a need in San Francisco for a hip, fun dining experience with great food, great service, great ambience. Go with friends expect to talk loud over hip hop, take plenty of soju shots and grub on some good Korean (even by LA standards)
author: Jacob K.

description:
My husband brought me here for my birthday, and it was a treat from beginning to end. It's my new favorite restaurant and I can't wait to go back.

We started with the kimchee & pickles, which was an array of small dishes, including outstanding marinated mushrooms and squid jerky that my son could not stop munching. The dumplings were delicious and came with a salad that was surprisingly refreshing and rich. We also had the chicken wings, a good sized portion of crunchy goodness. The kalbi lettuce wraps were so good we practically licked the plate. We also ordered a stack of ribs that were sticky sweet hot and melted in our mouths.

The service was excellent as well, attentive and helpful. I can't say enough good things about this place!
author: Meghan C.

description: Absolutely loved our dinner experience! The chicken and ribs were amazing and the frozen cocktails were delicious.  This place has a great vibe and will definitely be coming back.
author: Zack S.

description: Just went to this new hotspot in the Mission for the second time.  Very lively atmosphere with great food and friendly service.  Foxsister provides comfortable seating in large red booths or great action at the bat. The menu is a mix of some authentic dishes as well as some with a little more American flare. If your menu choices lean to the hotter side, be sure to get one of the soju slushee to quell the fire ( watermelon-ginger is my favorite). Had the same server on both occasions.  She was super friendly, very well informed and knowledgeable about the menu.  Will definitely go back!
author: Kraig B.

description: Had dinner here last night and really enjoyed it. Very busy but the service was great, from the hostess and server :) Fried chicken and spicy pork was pretty good. Drink selection was a big plus. Fun and great variety. Coming back soon and definitely recommend for a fun, casual dinner with friends.  Only con: one bathroom for men and women so that wasn't really good for such a busy place but I guess that's not too unusual for SF.
author: N. V.

description:
This place is awesome !! As soon as you walk inside you are transported to a world of 1980's punk with disco glam and a punch of nostalgia from a place I had no idea I was missing. This all is just to get you in the mood for what's to come from the kitchen and bar. 
The menu is playful yet true to Korean cuisine. Meant to be shared family style and enjoyed by everyone in your table. The fried chicken is amazing !!!! I recommend it you get "Around the world" so you can try all three flavors. (Sweet & Spicy, Ginger soy, OG). The Banchan, pork & beef dumplings, Oxtail Stew, Kalbi short rib, Pork fried rice was what we ordered. Every bite was on point ! One bite better the the rest. From the bar the soju slushies are so refreshing and surprisingly strong ! Our experience was unbelievable!! We are coming back tomorrow
author: Jacinto C.

description: Saw this new Korean restaurant on Yelp with excellent reviews. Brought my fellow foodie friend to get an extra set of taste bud. To our disappointment, they were out of the glazed pork ribs and the spicy octopus rice cakes, but there were plenty of other mouth watering sounding items on the menu. We ended up ordering the kimchi nacho dip, the sweet chili chicken wings, the kimchi hellfire stew and the spicy pork bulgogi. The kimchi nacho dip came with lotus chips and giant pork grinds, very creative. The dip was pretty good but we really couldn't taste any kimchi. The kimchi hellfire stew had little spices, which begs the question why call it hellfire? The sweet chili chicken wings were large, crispy and juicy. However, they were too salty and really didn't taste sweet nor spicy. The spicy pork bulgogi we thought was on point. Had very good flavor! The lettuce leaf wraps were an interesting side as opposed to the traditional steamed rice. Overall, we both agreed the food was good but not great, being on the pricey side.
author: John C.

description: Amazing restaurant with a friendly and knowledgeable staff. Try the Soju Slushies and the fried rice.
author: Ryan B.

description: I wanted to take my boyfriend to a new spot in SF for an early birthday celebration and I came across Foxsister. I made reservations for 2 at 6pm without realizing the restaurant didn't open until 6pm so it was actually perfect timing! We ordered white rice, a Stack (5 pieces) of Slow Cooked Ribs, and Spicy Pork Bulgogi to share. The ribs had incredibly rich flavor and the meat was literally falling off the bone. They were well-cooked, well-coated in sauce, and we finished them off easily. The Spicy Pork Bulgogi was sizzling when it arrived at our table and came complete with lettuce wraps. It was a refreshing relief from all the heat (flavor/temperature) and my boyfriend was absolutely in love with the flavor. We definitely crave spicy foods so this pair was perfection. Our server was fantastic, checked on us multiple times, and gave us much needed extra lettuce wraps to eat up everything! I also loved the décor and ambiance. Normally I gravitate away from establishments that are low lit but with the mirror mosaic, candlelit tables, and Bone Thugs-N-Harmony bumpin there really was nothing to complain about. No photos of the food because it was THAT amazing. My bf really enjoyed himself and we will definitely return!
author: Becca S.

description: Just what the neighborhood needs! But really, it is! Its fun, its got amazing food and Korean food is so under represented in this area! The ambiance is amazing.. they have a HOT PINK GLITTER BAR!! They also have a birthday cupcake for dessert because every day should be your birthday! If you knew me, you would know this is my life motto!! Also my friends joke that I am a vegetarian on the inside because of how picky I am with meat stuffs and let me tell you I ate the shit out of some ribs here.. they were so juicy and tender they fell of the bone and so i wasnt creeped out!! Also the dumplings! and the noodle salad and the chicken in 3 flavors! OMG! I died and turned into a ghost while at FoxSister because it was too perfect. I dont drink but if i did soju slushies would be my #1 beverage of choice guaranteed! Literally best new restaruant in SF!  HANDS DOWN!!
author: Danielle M.

description:
I'll give this place another shot at some point -- especially since I live pretty close. Main gripes:
* music way too loud
* too trendy
* foods good but not $50 per person good (app drink and main)

Likes:
* great decor
* good service, everyone friendly

The food is Korean-ish -- definitely catered towards the western palette, while also being reminiscent of Korean. 

It's a nice place -- just not a staple at this point.
author: Sumeet S.

description:
The food and the ambience is here is fun, creative and a great place to chill with friends. Classic Korean dishes with a twist. 

The soju slushies are the best thing on this earth and a must try. Especially that Rose, it is fire!!!
author: Christopher K.

description:
- having to pay for ban chan at a Korean place is wack
- overpriced for what you get. Dinner for two with two entrees, ban chan, one rice, two alcoholic drinks came to ~$50/person after tip
- there is much better valued Korean food in SF
author: Alex M.

description:
a large group of us had dinner here last night to celebrate a friend's birthday.  we arrived early for drinks, enjoyed a sampling of slushies, all of which were amazing, and then had dinner.
everything was DELICIOUS and the service was thoughtful.  no doubt all 13 of us will be back for more very soon!
author: Kelly O.

description: Finally a Korean place in the Mission. Well, not really. The Banjan is not free and kind of pricey for what you get. The menu is pretty limited though judging by other peoples comments they seem to change it. Many of the dishes were too salty, none were spicy even if "fire" was in the name. If you are dying for Korean tasting food and don't have time to get to a good place, this will do if you don't mind the high prices.
author: Marlin L.

description: First time having Korean style food and loved every dish. Especially liked that it's served family style. Great service, great food, great atmosphere...5 stars!
author: Lissette I.

description: Edible but aggressively mediocre. Then banchan was ok. Pork fried rice was bland but ok. The fried chicken was oversalted.
author: Noam S.

description: Went here 2 weeks ago with my 7 year old   Place was almost completely empty. I asked for a table the host asked if I had reservations I did not. She looked at my daughter and said we don't have any available tables until 10pm. The hostess was unfriendly in her delivery and it was obvious from her look that we were not welcome. This place is definitely not family friendly. Don't bother.
author: Kyra I.

description: Delicious! We had a reservation on Friday night at 6p when the place opened, and there was already a line forming when we arrived early. When we were seated, it seemed like entire restaurant was already full! We ordered the chicken "around the world", a few pieces of each flavor, octopus rice cakes, and the kimchi nachos for an appetizer. Everything was delicious, but I would say that the octopus and kimchi nachos stood out to me the most even though the place has been blogged about for their chicken. We split these items among two of us and had leftovers--I think this would have been perfect for three hungry people, or expect to bring food home. I found myself talking about this place for a few weeks after I went and have already recommended it to friends. Be prepared to talk loudly--it's got a bit of a clubby scene, and there's only one bathroom, if that matters to you. Anyway, it's great and I'll be back again soon!
author: Amanda W.

description: It had been a long day of being on my feet when I decided to rest by popping into Foxsister. I didn't know what to expect as I'm fairly new to the city and hadn't been to this part of town before so I went in with no expectations. Upon entering I was greeted by an ethereal goddess of a woman. She had short, bleached hair and an eyebrow piercing that highlighted her strong brows and stunning ice blue eyes. Suddenly, I was hungry for more than the  Korean food I could smell coming from the kitchen. She sat me at the bar and I couldn't take my eyes off her the entire time I ate my spicy octopus rice cakes. I will hopefully return soon with enough guts to order her octopus cakes.
author: Noah L.

description: They have makgeolli! We fell in love with that stuff in Korea. It's kind of like carbonated unfiltered sake. We shared a bottle and a Hite beer. The decor is so kitschy and awesome. The mural outside is punchy and gorgeous, and all the little decor elements inside make it feel funky and fun. The menu is hard to read - we almost couldn't find the fried chicken because it's in a different color than the rest of the items. The drink menu had a ton of great beer (some Asian brands and some local craft stuff) and soju slushies - it might be one of my favorite drink menus ever. The banchan were all wonderful - must order to go with everything else. Korean Fried Chicken was great - the sweet and spicy sauce was perfect with a citrusy note that made them addictive. The order of fried oysters was large (probably 10-12 oysters) and the breading was phenomenal. We got talked into the yuba bulgogi by the server but I wish we had ordered the crab noodles like we originally wanted. I think if served with rice the yuba bulgogi would be good but it didn't really work as a wrap. Service was fast and friendly. We will definitely be back - I want to try the crab noodles and kimchi nacho cheese dip! One small drawback is that it's pretty expensive - but Korean fusion in SF tends to be pricey. Luckily the delicious food and awesome atmosphere make it worth the $$.
author: Tanya K.

description: This is one of the best restaurants I've been to in a long time! We had fried oysters, tofu kimchi dumplings, pork dumplings, crab glass noodles, fried chicken, ribs and pork bulgogi. Every single dish was delicious!! I loved the ambiance, dark walls, dim lighting and great music. This will definitely be a regular spot for me!
author: Jen G.

description: Holy moly! So happy to have them in the neighborhood. Innovative, modern and hip. The Yuba bulgogi blew my mind.
author: Tatiana C.

description: This place is truly amazing. It may be the most unique restaurant in the city. The design is rad, they call it "trash glam" and the term totally fits!  The food is both casual yet there is a sense that the ingredients are of a higher caliber than at typical Korean restaurants and the cooks in the kitchen are clearly professionals. This may be the perfect mission district restaurant!
author: DG G.

description: worst korean food experience i've ever had. we got the banchan (probably the best thing out of everything we got), oxtail in marrow broth (the meat was tender and good), grilled kalbi short rib (came nearly 50 minutes after everything else because of a kitchen delay; was mediocre to say the least), and some fried chicken which was well cooked but bland as a banana. now this may seem like an ok review, but i had diarrhea 20 minutes after we left the restaurant. maybe they had an off day but i'm never going back. the service was not outstanding either, the waitress just never bothered to update us on the main course delay. 2/10 rating for the whole experience.
author: Brenda F.

description: While we waited for a bit for our table even though we had a reservation, it was well worth the wait! The ambience is loud with some bass thumping hip hop which I loved. We enjoyed the salad they had on the menu, the dungeoness crab noodles and a rack of ribs and everything was really delicious! Definitely will be back, the service was outstanding!
author: Lia F.

description: Delicious and celiac safe! Really nice to have multiple options to pick from that are gluten free. And there are tasty options with gluten for non celiacs too.
author: Kelly G.

description: Great fun and hip spot. Excellent for a drink and some ribs. Great vibe, cool place to bring any non sf peeps to feel some city energy. Also great place to catch a game and a beer. It's busy on a Friday or sat so check it out on an off night to really stretch out and chat up the bar tender!
author: Gabriel H.

description: This place rules! Man, I read some of the 2-3 star reviews and the you guys are cray! $8 for 6 banchan isn't a bad deal. I could tell they use the best ingredients (unlike regular K BBq) kimchi was on point, delicious chewy squid jerky, kimchi cucumber, sweet potato salad, soy mushrooms (my favorites) and pickled soy bean sprouts. The decor was fresh! Sparking purple bar, awesome wheat paste art, killer punkrock play list, and super helpful excellent service. Good beer and wine selection. I had a glass of Lambrusco and it was thee best I've ever had. We had the octopus rice cakes which were excellent, then we had the kimchi stew which had these delicious little chunks of pork belly. We also had the ribs that just fell off the bone, a little sweet and a little spicy. The Kalbi short ribs and pork Bulgolgi were served with lettuce wraps and were definitely the star of the show.  Everything was seasoned perfectly. It cost about $50 a person which if you've ever gone out to eat in SF ain't that expensive. I usually don't Yelp much but after reading some of these ridiculous low star reviews I was compelled to set the record straight. This place is a Newley discovered gem and I highly recommend it.
author: John R.
